part.title: Use notable types
part.para: RES takes rdf:type statements about resources and maps them to one of a small number of generic classes. These classes are used to group similar resources together in partitions to assist discovery. The full list of partitions can be browsed at http://acropolis.org.uk/.

Inclusion of a resource in a RES partition depends on it having a specific type, or a type which can be mapped to that specific type. The list below shows each partition and the type(s) a resource should have to be put into it:

seglistitem.seg: Creative works (e.g. novels, plays, articles, paintings, photographs)
frbr:Work (generally), schema:Photograph for photographs, schema:AudioObject for sounds
foaf:Document for documents, DCMI Types for other types of asset
People (i.e. real people who are living or dead, and fictional characters)

tip.para: It's not essential for a resource to end up in a partition, but if it does, it will be more visible to a user browsing RES's index.

section.title: Adding types to the museum's resources
section.para: Returning to the example of items in the museum, the helmet is a physical thing. To be included in the physical things partition, a resource must either have the type crm:E18_Physical_Thing or a type which maps onto it. (RES's mappings between types are in Acropolis' rulebase configuration.)

One type which is mapped to crm:E18_Physical_Thing is crm:E22_Man-Made_Object, so the museum applies that to the helmet resource. This is a term from the CIDOC-CRM vocabulary, which was designed for cultural heritage data, making it ideally suited to describing things in a museum.
The museum's other resources are assigned types to slot them into RES's partitions, yielding the following RDF:
section.programlisting:
# the helmet - will go in "Physical things" <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/data/items/t0001#id> a crm:E22_Man-Made_Object .
# the document about the helmet - will go in "Digital assets" <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/data/items/t0001> a foaf:Document .
# the photograph - will go in "Creative works"; # note that schema:Photograph is used as this maps to frbr:Work <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/data/photos/p0001#id> a schema:Photograph .
# the document about the photograph - will go in "Digital assets" <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/data/photos/p0001> a foaf:Document .
# the digital file representing the photograph - will go in "Digital assets"; # see the section below about RES's special treatment of DCMI Type resources <http://castleofotranto.org.uk/images/the-helmet-photo.jpg> a dcmitype:StillImage .

section.title: The importance of DCMI Type resources
section.para: The museum's digital asset was assigned the type dcmitype:StillImage in the preceding RDF. The main purpose of this, rather than slotting the resource into one of RES's partitions, is to make it discoverable via a related media search. This type of search enables a user to find things which have related media files (a common use case for applications powered by RES). Only resources which have a type from the DCMI Type vocabulary will be returned for this type of search.
Here's an outline of the logic behind related media searches:
section.programlisting: If resource A is associated with resource B (via any predicate) and resource B has the type dcmitype:T then a search for resources with related media of type dcmitype:T will return A

This returns all resources with a property value matching the string "Dench", where those resources are related to other resources which have the type http://purl.org/dc/dcmitype/StillImage.
